dublin_core.dcvalue: Modern medical concerns with telemedicine and robotics practiced across national or other jurisdictional boundaries engage the historical complex area of law called conflict of laws An initial concern is whether a practitioner licensed only in jurisdiction A who treats a patient in jurisdiction B violates B s laws Further concerns are whether a practitioner in A who violates a contract or treats a patient in B negligently incurs liability in B A or both and if treatment lawful in A is unlawful in B whether the practitioner commits a crime Judicial procedures are set by courts in which proceedings are initiated but courts may decline jurisdiction due to inconvenience to parties If courts accept jurisdiction they may apply their own substantive legal rules but may find that the rules of a conflicting jurisdiction should apply Cross border care should not change usual medical ethics for instance on confidentiality but may mitigate or aggravate migration of specialists
International journal of gynaecology and obstetrics: the official organ of the International Federation of Gynaecology and Obstetrics
Legal and ethical issues in telemedicine and robotics.
